titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ivan Kats Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Richard Richie and Christy Tomecek

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 11:44

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The Ivan Kats papers are comprised of correspondence, drafts of Obor Foundation publications and translations, Obor Foundation financial information, reports from the Congress for Cultural Freedom, photographs from Kats' travels in Indonesia, and three Indonesian anti-communist posters. Correspondence with journalist, publisher, novelist, and key Obor Foundation contributor Muchtar Lubis, between 1969 and 1983, comprises a large portion of the collection, as does Kats' correspondence with many other Indonesian intellectuals and officials. Of particular interest are the drafts and correspondence related to an unpublished volume, Indonesia 1958-1965: The Cultural Scene which Kats organized between 1966 and 1967. Contributors include Indonesian intellectuals Andre Hardjana, Rosihan Anwar and S. Tasrif, with several drafts in both English and Indonesian.

langmaterial.language: The material is primarily in English and Indonesian.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged in six series: I. Unpublished work, Cultural Scene , 1961-1968. II. The Obor Foundation, 1950-2002. III. The Congress for Cultural Freedom, 1960-1990. IV. 30 September Movement, 1964-1966. V. Personal correspondence and writings, 1948-2006. VI. Photographs and posters, 1965-1966.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Born in the Netherlands, Ivan Kats spent the majority of his adult life in France and the United States, where he worked as a translator, editor, teacher, journalist and publisher. While living in France during the 1960s, Kats worked for the Congress for Cultural Freedom (CCF) – an anti-communist advocacy group founded in Paris – that established magazines, held conferences and art shows, and supported a number of poets, authors, and artists across 35 countries worldwide. Until his departure from the CCF in 1966, Kats was primarily engaged in a program for sending books and other publications to anti-communist, opposition leaders in Indonesia. After the 30 September Movement, and the ouster of the Indonesian President Sukarno in 1967, Kats left France and moved to New Haven, Connecticut, where he became affiliated with the Council on South East Asian Studies at Yale University. Between 1970 and his retirement in 1996, Kats functioned as director of Buku Obor (Yayasan Obor Indonesia), or the Obor Foundation, an organization he founded, dedicated to the publication and dissemination of books to book-poor countries. Initially focused on Indonesia, Obor spread to several other countries including Pakistan and Morocco, where they translated and published books in Urdu and Arabic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Ivan Kats papers are comprised of correspondence, drafts of Obor Foundation publications and translations, Obor Foundation financial information, reports from the Congress for Cultural Freedom, photographs from Kats' travels in Indonesia, and three Indonesian anti-communist posters. Correspondence with journalist, publisher, novelist, and key Obor Foundation contributor Muchtar Lubis, between 1969 and 1983, comprises a large portion of the collection, as does Kats' correspondence with many other Indonesian intellectuals and officials. Of particular interest are the drafts and correspondence related to an unpublished volume, Indonesia 1958-1965: The Cultural Scene which Kats organized between 1966 and 1967. Contributors include Indonesian intellectuals Andre Hardjana, Rosihan Anwar and S. Tasrif, with several drafts in both English and Indonesian.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Ivan Kats Papers (MS 2048). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Nicolas Kats, 2008. Transferred from the Southeast Asia Collection Curator, 2016.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes drafts, outlines of articles, and related correspondence for the unpublished essay collection Cultural Scene . Cultural Scene was proposed to discuss academic and cultural life in Indonesia in the seven years preceding the 30 September movement. Materials are arranged by document type.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes correspondence, publications, financial documents, and other official documents pertaining to the Obor Foundation, the nonprofit organization that Kats founded and directed. Arranged by document type.

did.unittitle: United States Agency for International Development financial reports
Mochtar Buchori curriculum vitae and writing
Economic Development as a Cultural Problem by Soedjatmoko
An Approach to Indonesian History Towards an Open Future by Soedjatmoko

From Mochtar Lubis' Tjatatan Dalam Tahanan (notes from the detention barraks) by P.K. Auwjong

Summary of publishing in North Africa
Ivan Kats notebooks from Rockefeller sponsored conferences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of reports and articles written by and on the Congress for Cultural Freedom (CCF), an anti-Communist organization. The documents focus on general work by the CCF, including work done in Asia, but do not focus on Kats's specific projects.

did.unittitle: "Congress Informations Pour la Liberté de la Culture: April-May 1960/March-May 1964"
"Towards the Open Community: Human Ideals and Social Difficulties"
"Report to the Ford Foundation on Western European Studies and Opinion on East Asia: October 12, 1965"
"The Asian Institute of International Relations: A Proposal"
"What was the Congress for Cultural Freedom? By Hilton Kramer"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains handwritten and typed reports on the 30 September Movement, information on the members of the movement, and a newspaper article. Some of the material appears to be written by Kats.

did.unittitle: List of Indonesian intellectuals and press with notes
"Graveside Eulogy Rallies a Nation," clipping from The Australian

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes correspondence with individuals and a small amount of writing, mainly related to the Obor Foundation. None of the correspondence is exhaustive; there are one or two letters or packets per correspondent.

unittitle.title: How to Develop a Publishing Industry in a Book-Poor Country
The Story of the Obor Foundation: An Indonesian Experience for Replication?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs of Kats and colleagues as well as three anti-Communist posters.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Some photographs had identifying information written on paper and taped to them; to preserve the photograph, this was removed. Photographs were put in sleeves and a label with the information is attached to the backside of the sleeve holding the photograph.

did.unittitle: Photographs of Ivan Kats and associates during work with Obor Foundation
